results.content:
As a "non-tech" guy, I know the anxiety associated with trying to find a tech person to build out my idea while knowing NOTHING technical myself.  After much denial, I came to realize that this was a terrible position to be in because not only was I at the mercy of the technical crowd, but I also lacked complete agency in thinking that my ideas NEEDED to be created by someone else.  Going into the tech space without an ounce of knowledge how to code just doesn't make much sense, no matter how you coat it.    

Enter: Coding for Entrepreneurs.  This course will allow you to finally break free from the assumption that if you haven't been coding since 15, then it's pointless/too hard to start now.  Justin shows you step-by-step how to build a working landing page from scratch that can then be designed to your taste.  Very great for the person without any prior coding experience, or the person looking to apply the tech skills they acquired on sites like Codecademy.      

For folks totally new to coding, like myself, who want to delve deeper in the topics, I would suggest analyzing the videos over and over again and supplementing with the Django Documentation (for Python), as he suggests, or Codecademy (for Python and HTML/CSS).    

Start today, and jump right in.  The progress you make is addictive, inspiring, and crazily rewarding.  Had it not been for Coding For Entrepreneurs, I'd be at the next tech Meetup hoping to meet someone that would build my product.  Thank goodness that's no longer my approach!  Kudos to Justin.

results.content:
Finally finished this course by Justin and I must say that it is really good. Everyone learns differently and for me I found that I needed to do stop the course and get through some additional material in order to "make everything clear" but that's just me.

The course takes you into the basics of Django in order for you to see how it functions and you will also find that there is enough information here about front end to get you interested in trying things on your own. However the biggest positive about this course was that Justin was on hand to answer questions and even reached out via email to offer encouragement to actually finish the class. It meant a lot!! Thanks Justin

While I am still not fully able to build EVERYTHING I need to get my idea off the ground, I am in a much better spot and can actually "ask the right questions" to my programmer friends when seeking help. 

Take the risk and try this course. If you are a total beginner, you may be lost a lot but go through materials on Python or even the short Django tutorial on www.djangoproject.com then return to this course. It is the first course I've encountered that takes you from a blank editor and incorporates front and back end to create a functional site.

Keep practicing!!

And the instructors themselves are incredible at responding to questions quickly and accurately!  There are a couple videos that could be refreshed/added to fix a couple confusing steps/clarify certain parts of the setup & install processes, but they're immaterial at this point.

results.content:
When I took this course (July 2015), most of the material appeared to be a little over a year old, which admittedly doesn't seem like it was all that long ago. But after completing the course, building out a project, and doing way too many stack overflow searches, I discovered that major components of the coursework involved methods that had been made simpler or obsolete by subsequent Django releases. Frustrating, to say the least.

On that same note, it would tremendously behoove the instructor to rethink the material itself with the goal of helping learners build/scale platforms in the wild. 3 specific examples: 

1) Publishing. Currently, the process of transitioning the app from a local dev environment to Heroku is way harder than it has to be. If the app is going to launch on Heroku, then start from that perspective and make full use of the available tools (i.e. Heroku Toolbelt).

2) Scaffolding and Package-handling: Tools like Yeoman and Bower make life way easier for folks like us who are generally non-technical. They should be an integral part of the course.

3) Databases. I know it's not a database course, but at least an overview of how to move from SQLlite (which doesn't jive with Heroku and isn't great for production anyway) to PostgreSQL would be extremely helpful.

Additionally, the entire course is structured around, references, and at times flatly becomes an advertisement for the instructor's site/learning platform. I understand the impulse to simply transplant the videos from one platform to another without making edits, but doing so creates a frustrating experience for users.

results.content:
I was excited about the course, having some background in Python and working at a company that uses Django. Things started off easily enough, but I soon realized an issue with the instruction style: it's literal. As in, "I will now read to you what I'm typing without giving much context as to why we're doing this."

The concept of "learning by building" is great, but without context and proper explanation, you're just copying code. And while that is, in fact, one way to learn, it's definitely not the ideal one. So two stars, because I will admit I learned a few things, but I'll be furthering my education elsewhere.

results.content:
Justin Mitchel is one of the best, and most motivated instructors I have learned from,
Django/Python + Bootstrap is fantastic when used together to make websites.

He has taught me (in a few short weeks time) how to make a "minimal viable product" website, where I control the backend (Django/Python) AND the frontend (Bootstrap),
I can now setup this developer-environment on Linux, Mac OSX and Windows.

For years I struggled with ASP/PHP/Drupal, but this course has already taught me enough to feel comfortable, knowing that I can FINALLY become a good web programmer and (later on) start making money and hopefully start my own web-business, using Django/Python+Bootstrap as my (now) preferred developer tools!

I HIGHLY recommend this course to a new student, if you are serious about learning good future-proof skills in web development.

Thank you Justin!

This course could be vastly improved in several ways:  1) if the lessons were thought out/written in advance of recording.  2) Give an overall structure and strategy of how each lesson or group of lessons relate to real word tasks for entrepreneurs.  The course feels like it was jumbled together by a junior software engineer hopped up on too much caffeine and not enough daylight.

results.content:
So far I really like the course and I believe it is very helpful for anyone who wants to learn Django. There are just two caveats (the reasons why I didn't give five stars):

1. I don't believe a person with zero programming experience will have much fun with the Course. I have some small experience with Python (mostly for data science) and some HTML. Both really helped to understand what the instructor did. I believe without that Prior Knowledge I would have to Research a lot more online.
2. The instructor uses an Apple Computer. So what he enters into the command line might not correspond to what a PC user has to enter. He does say "as a PC user you have to enter this...", but at least once it was actually a tiny bit different and I had to research some time on my own what to write instead.

results.content:
I am new to programming and python(video editor/producer/director by trade).  As I learned python I wanted to also learn more web development along side my python learning.  Django was the clear choice, but I ran into a problem.  The internet IS NOT FILLED with django tutorials.  I had to do some real digging to find anything.  In my search I found most django tutorials where out of date.  I came a crossed udemy and found Justin's tutorial serious and I was very excited to try.  I paid my money and started my adventure.  
I am not finished but in the first few lectures he does a great job walking you though setting up eveything you need to get started on a django project. This was a huge contrast from some of the other django tutorials out there.  They are just not made for the beginner. Another huge thing is you can ask question and they get answered. Most of the time from Justin.
Also with his tutorials it's not just django or python. You get some SQL, HTML, CSS and every thing else you need to get a website off the ground.

I am looking forward to finished the course and doing some of my own project.  

Thanks Justin!

results.content: I do like the hands on approach to do by learning, but I just do not feel like its the proper way to really become a web developer or build your own product. What I feel happens at least in my experience is I get stuck when I have issues, want to change, add or manipulate what I am building. I then troll internet forums, google, and stack overload for answers to copy and paste which may or may not even solve my problem. I feel like even if we are to copy and paste if the instructor would slow down and explain each part (as long as that might take) it would make a lot more sense. Truly understanding python is much more beneficial as well for this course to be very useful although having a finished product is cool! Great course if you just want something finished to launch. Unfortunately your code will have control of you rather than the other way around since we dont really learn django and python.
